messages: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:59): Being able to set HTTP headers used in hyperlinks from HTML seems to have a very poor backward compaibility story
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:07): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: No, no. HTTP has supported headers for many years ;)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:22): It opens up all kinds of attack vectors
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (22:26): is scheme:path?query;param#anchor the correct format, or is it scheme:path;param?query#anchor ?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:27): I believe it's the latter
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:45): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I think Macrovision on VHS isn't *DRM*, because it lacks the D
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:45): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Pedant :)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:46): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: it seems to me that the argument is:
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:47): 1) Font foundries want to make infringing people aware that they are infringing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:48): 2) People grab a font using view source / Web Inspector / Firebug don't realize they are infringing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:49): so the argument doesn't hinge on any technical prevention
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:49): but on what hoops make people aware that they are infringing when they infringe
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:49): Then any obstruction or DRM is overkill
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:50): s/grab/who grab/

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:51): Would it not be simpler for browsers to include a small note in all save boxes, along the lines of, "This file may be subject to copyright/licence restrictions."
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:52): I don't see why that is needed
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:53): or how it would help, really
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:53): Nor do I really, but it seems to address the needs of the foundries

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:54): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: the whole discussion is basically about what rituals would make one group of believe that another group of people is lead to think in a certain way
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:55): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Yeah, but putting randon pseudo-legalese in browsers is really not nice
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:57): I still don't understand why fonts deserve more protection than photographs
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:57): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I agree. Particularly when the pseudo-legalese is a truism that should be assumed to be known by default.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:57): "&lt a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554> Nor do I really, but it seems to address the needs of the foundries" assumes that we need to address those needs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:57): which i'm pretty sure we don't
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:58): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Just ignore the font foundries?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:58): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Surely that's no different to ignoring implementers?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:58): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: That seems like an option.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:58): (in terms of getting stuff used)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:00): implementors can veto stuff because if they don't implement, the spec is fiction
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:00): font foundries have no veto ability here, and their needs directly conflict with the users'
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:00): users win
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:00): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: what happened with Google's EOT patch for WebKit?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:01): we decided we couldn't justify introducing DRM given our "do no evil" principles
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: No, users don't win. They can't use the majority of fonts.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:01): sure they can
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:02): (and if you just send OTF/TTF anyway, who's betting the foundries will just change their licences to disallow that)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:02): of the fonts available to a random author, the vast majority are free

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:02): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: it seems to me that the "need" of foundries is to believe that users know what they are infringing. I'm not convinced that in would be against the users' needs to know what behaviors are infringing. However, I'd prefer a way to establish the belief and awareness without using technology as a intermediate.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:03): users are fully aware that copying a font from another site is a violation of copyright
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:03): so that need is already met
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (23:03): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: That is hardly a unique need. Why do fonts get special consideration over all other media

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:06): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: yeah, according to a recent study conducted in Finland, 95% of school kids believe that distributing movies and music without authorization is illegal.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:07): people know it's illegal, they just don't care
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:12): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: You say "believe", makes it sound like it isn't :)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:14): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: well, I'm pretty sure it's illegal here, but these studies also include BS about using the word that approximates "felony" for things that are illegal but not punishable
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:14): (compare with riding a bike without a helmet)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:15): The jail/no jail distinction?

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:16): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: for example, I'm pretty sure that downloading movies / music without authorization is in the illegal but not punishable category here.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:16): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: but the people who get prosecuted also shared the content
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:16): If it's not punishable, what would stop anyone from doing it?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:17): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: knowing that it illegal. And for all things not copyright-related, Finns will generally obey the law on the law's sayso
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:18): Also, over here the police can do pretty much what it pleases and can use equipment confiscation as a de facto punishment on a presumed guilty-basis.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:21): Given how many people infringe copyright even when they know it's illegal, I can't imagine many are put off by it being considered legally naughty but not punishable

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:21): I would guess that for people who are very familiar with the law and practice, the risk of equipment confiscation without judicial oversight is a stronger deterrent than the law
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:27): (oh. there's another thing that's illegal but not punishable and that people do: lying about campaign finance to the ministry of justice)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:28): (the politicians had the good sense to make their own illegalities non-punishable)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:30): I learned in class that illegal was defined as there being a law against it
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:32): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: right. But the law doesn't have to set punishments for all things that are illegal.

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:33): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: and over here if an illegal thing doesn't have an entry in the Criminal Code, it's a different type of illegality than a "crime"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:35): So what happens if the police find you committing one of those crimes? They take your computer to gather evidence, and then throw the evidence away?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:37): copyright violation is punishable
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:37): it's just a civil offense rather than a criminal one
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:37): which means financial damages and reparations, generally
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:38): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Finland doesn't have punitive damages, so in theory, if it's a civil case, it's not a punisment but just damages
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:38): *punishment
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:38): and what's the nominal "damage" of violating copyright?

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:40): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: they can take the computers and all inessential related equipment away for investigation, be slow with the investigation, and turn over the evidence to support a trial brought by a RIAA/MPAA/IFPI-connected civil association
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:40): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: the retail price of the same piece of content on CD/DVD
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:41): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: assuming a theory that every copy is a lost sale, which is of course bogus
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:41): wow, that's low
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (23:41): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: better than the RIAA's theory
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:41): the us has insanely high numbers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:41): like, ever violation is 5 digits usd
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:41): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: plus legal fees!
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (23:41): i.e., every copy represents thousands of lost sales
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:41): every, even
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:42): so if you lose a case to the enforcement association, the court orders you to pay their legal fees
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:42): so for the downloader case, the main risk is equipment confiscation and legal fees
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:43): for the uploader case, there's also a potentially high supposed damage
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:43): none of these are "punishments" in the legal sense although de facto, they are

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:46): not having punitive damages is good. If something requires more punishment, a fine to the state leads to much more healthy behavior than awarding more than the actual damages to the supposedly injured party

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:47): (the reason why we don't have punitive damages is a principle that the injured party shouldn't end up better off than where they started by suffering a damage)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:49): you'll note i didn't mention punitive damages :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:49): i don't think the us has them for copyright violations either
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:49): but what do i know
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:49): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: well, the U.S. has crazy statutory damages
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:49): It's not like the actual law matters to the RIAA :P
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:49): I'm not sure if those are considered "punitive" legally in this case
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (23:52): how about cruel and unusual?

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:52): anyway, damages in excess of the actual damages whether statutory or made up be a judge on the spot suck, and it's better to put the excess into the state treasure than to award it to another litigant, IMO
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:53): statutory damages kinda makes sense in that for non-financial stuff there has to be some sort of going rate for pain
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:53): i mean, it's not like you can easily measure the pain cause by slander in USD, for example
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (23:54): slanders 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e's cat
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:54): poor mowmow
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:54): they were at the vet this morning
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (23:54): has a cat who likes to sit and sleep
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (23:54): very good paperweight
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:54): a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9: it seems to me that in RIAA cases damages are cruel but unfortunately not unusual
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:56): s/treasure/treasury/
